ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned very useful vocabulary and terms that could be used if living and working in China. I also enjoyed the topics and thought they helped me learn more about Chinese culture and history.
Chinese vocabulary, sentence structure, and culture for our units, including marriage, online dating, and economic growth.
I improved in my fluency and learned a lot of vocabulary relating to sociopolitical topic. I improved in essay writing and public speaking.
I learned many new vocabulary words and grammar structures for writing formal essays.
I really expanded my vocabulary. A lot of great opportunities to practice speaking and writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Sometimes homework or other assignments would not be uploaded to Canvas until very late the day before the class - it would be helpful for these files and assignments to be uploaded early to allow students to plan for their week.

Strengths: felt very modern and applicable
Weaknesses: none

The greatest strength was the insistence on oral essays and presentations. These really helped me work in my Chinese fluency

The workload was occasionally overburdening, as we had to learn a large amount of vocabulary words almost nightly. If we had learned less words but reinforced the ones we knew, I might be more familiar with vocabulary. Many of the vocabulary learns were also repeats from 150 and 151.

Lastly, I think the tests could have been more challenging, and we should have done debates more than once. The students were really tired during they first debate but I think that was mainly because it took place on a Monday. If we had been given more notice for other debates we would have been more energetic.
The strengths are that you learn to write really well, but I think they should bring back weekly speaking exercises since speaking is such a vital part of language study.

It is a really low pressure environment to learn Chinese. A lot of content is thrown at you and you are not necessarily expected to pick up everything. Opportunities to practice are great. 

Only weakness I would say is that some of the homework assignments feel nit-picky; they are canvas quizzes that require you to answer exactly correctly.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely - it was very helpful for anyone wanting to live and work in China, or just learn Chinese overall.
Yes. I felt that the material was very relevant and Professor Liang was extremely understanding and kind.

I am not sure why levels 158 and 159 exist in the Chinese curriculum and students are kept from immediately staking more specialized Chinese courses. If a student can take 150 and 151 and then travel abroad, I think that is a more effective way to learn Chinese. However, I would recommend this courses to a student who wants to obtain the Chinese certificate but cannot study abroad, or who wants more general Chinese practice.
Yes. Definitely. This class is intellectually challenging and your Chinese will improve greatly; at the same time, it is quite low-pressure.
